docs.abstract: Nearly 50,000 people defy claims that 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre in Beijing is fading into time by staging candlelight vigil in Hong Kong in memory of protestors who died; (S)

headline.main: Killings at Tiananmen Remembered in Hong Kong

docs.snippet: Defying claims that the memory of the 1989 killings around Tiananmen Square is fading with time, nearly 50,000 people turned out here today to remember the protesters who died in Beijing.    The candlelight vigil here is the only public commemoration
docs.lead_paragraph: Defying claims that the memory of the 1989 killings around Tiananmen Square is fading with time, nearly 50,000 people turned out here today to remember the protesters who died in Beijing. The candlelight vigil here is the only public commemoration on Chinese soil of the massacre. While it draws a fraction of the one million people who poured into the streets here on June 4, 1989, it has become an annual exercise of the people's voice here amid the silence of China.

docs.abstract: Correction of May 6 Choice Tables review of Beijing restaurants; Shen Xuanhai, who once lived at site of Bamboo Garden Hotel, was businessman and government official, not palace eunuch (S)
docs.snippet: The Choice Tables column on May 6, about restaurants in Beijing, misidentified  Shen Xuanhai, owner of the home that is now the Bamboo Garden Hotel, site of the Drunken Beauty Veranda restaurant. A reader's e-mail message on May 10 pointed out that M
docs.lead_paragraph: The Choice Tables column on May 6, about restaurants in Beijing, misidentified Shen Xuanhai, owner of the home that is now the Bamboo Garden Hotel, site of the Drunken Beauty Veranda restaurant. A reader's e-mail message on May 10 pointed out that Mr. Shen was a prominent businessman and government official; he was not the Qing Dynasty palace eunuch who designed the gardens. This correction was delayed by a reporting lapse.

docs.abstract: Sheila Melvin article on resurgence of spoken drama in Beijing, which is largely credited to the directors Meng Jinghui and Lin Zhaohua; spoken drama is so called to distinguish it from traditional Chinese drama, which is sung; photos of Lin's staging of Lao She's epic drama Teahouse at Capital Theater and of Meng's staging of Vladimir Mayakovsky's The Bedbug at Beijing Children's Art Theater (M)

headline.main: Where New Theater Is Coming In From the Cold; Chinese Welcome a Break From Old-Style Drama

docs.snippet: THE Beijing Children's Art Theater is usually a place for puppet shows and children's plays, its comfortable purple seats filled with pampered only children and doting parents. But this winter the stalls were packed with snuggling young couples and c
docs.lead_paragraph: THE Beijing Children's Art Theater is usually a place for puppet shows and children's plays, its comfortable purple seats filled with pampered only children and doting parents. But this winter the stalls were packed with snuggling young couples and chattering college students, there to see one of the hottest shows in town, the China premiere of ''The Bedbug'' by Vladimir Mayakovsky. Meanwhile, just around the block, the Capital Theater was similarly filled to capacity for the final performance of a highly successful remake of Lao She's epic drama ''Teahouse.''

docs.abstract: china announces extensive plan to combat i

headline.main: China Announces Extensive Plan To Combat Its Water Shortage

docs.snippet: The Chinese government has announced details of a crash, multibillion-dollar plan it hopes will salvage the deteriorating water supply here, which along with other northern cities has suffered from years of unusually low rainfall and decades of unche
docs.lead_paragraph: The Chinese government has announced details of a crash, multibillion-dollar plan it hopes will salvage the deteriorating water supply here, which along with other northern cities has suffered from years of unusually low rainfall and decades of unchecked pollution and poorly planned development. The plan includes construction of new sewage-treatment plants, the closing of polluting factories, changes in farming practices and graduated pricing of water. It aims to ease the water shortage before Beijing can benefit from another grandiose project -- to pipe water from the Yangtze River basin in southern China to the north.

docs.abstract: Correction of May 6 Choice Tables column about restaurants in Beijing, which misspelled historical reference
docs.snippet: The Choice Tables column on May 6, about restaurants in Beijing, and a correction in this space on June 10 misspelled the names of the Qing Dynasty minister whose former home is the Bamboo Garden Hotel, site of the Drunken Beauty Veranda restaurant.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Choice Tables column on May 6, about restaurants in Beijing, and a correction in this space on June 10 misspelled the names of the Qing Dynasty minister whose former home is the Bamboo Garden Hotel, site of the Drunken Beauty Veranda restaurant. He was Sheng Xuanhuai, not Shen Xuanhai.

docs.abstract: Don King's deal to promote pay-per-view boxing card in Beijing is canceled when Rainbow Sports Networks, which had tentatively agree to distribute John Ruiz-Evander Holyfield fight scheduled for Aug 5 in Beijing, pulls out of deal (M)

headline.main: King Loses Distributor For Beijing Fight Card

docs.snippet: The announcement was to be made with all the pomp and grandiosity that Don King, the boxing promoter, has turned into his trademark. There were supposed to be Chinese dragon dancers winding their way through Radio City Music Hall yesterday. There wer
docs.lead_paragraph: The announcement was to be made with all the pomp and grandiosity that Don King, the boxing promoter, has turned into his trademark. There were supposed to be Chinese dragon dancers winding their way through Radio City Music Hall yesterday. There were supposed to be world champion heavyweights holding court. And there was supposed to be King himself, telling reporters about a pay-per-view deal he had worked out for the heavyweight bout in Beijing that he is promoting. But the news conference was unceremoniously canceled after Rainbow Sports Networks, which had tentatively agreed to distribute the John Ruiz-Evander Holyfield fight scheduled for Aug. 5 in Beijing, pulled out of the deal last Thursday night.

docs.abstract: Radio program called 'Hello Taxi' is particular favorite of Beijing's cabdrivers, as well as owners of swelling fleet of private cars; popular feature of program is driver's called-in taped anecdotes; cabdrivers say their job has become ever more frustrating, with nightmare traffic jams and need to work longer hours for fares that city reduced two years ago in effort to entice more riders; photo (M)

headline.main: Beijing Journal; Traffic Is a Mess, and Cabbies Find a Way to Vent

docs.snippet: Hop into a taxicab from the mad jangle of roads here any weekday morning, and there is a fair chance you will hear the soothing voice of Liang Hong on her radio program, ''Hello Taxi,'' often with John Denver's ''Take Me Home, Country Roads'' playing
docs.lead_paragraph: Hop into a taxicab from the mad jangle of roads here any weekday morning, and there is a fair chance you will hear the soothing voice of Liang Hong on her radio program, ''Hello Taxi,'' often with John Denver's ''Take Me Home, Country Roads'' playing in the background. The program, an homage to the humble cabdriver, has been a fixture of Beijing radio since 1993, occupying a prime morning hour on the main music station. In the city's ever more grasping atmosphere, the show and its main audience seem out of time. But the show remains popular with drivers of cabs, as well as owners of the swelling fleet of private cars, and advertisers seem to have noticed that when cabdrivers tune in, their passengers are most likely to listen, too.

docs.abstract: Article discusses Chinese reactions to performances and master classes by Paul Taylor Dance Company in Beijing; photo (M)

headline.main: Bikini Song And Popeye Please China

docs.snippet: When Popeye ruled Saturday morning television in the United States and ''Yellow Polka Dot Bikini'' was topping the music charts, the Chinese were in the throes of the Cultural Revolution, reading Little Red Books, condemning bourgeois capitalists, es
docs.lead_paragraph: When Popeye ruled Saturday morning television in the United States and ''Yellow Polka Dot Bikini'' was topping the music charts, the Chinese were in the throes of the Cultural Revolution, reading Little Red Books, condemning bourgeois capitalists, especially American, and raising their voices in revolutionary song. So it is not surprising that the audience at the Beijing Exhibition Center was perplexed recently when the Paul Taylor Dance Company bravely took to the stage with ''Funny Papers,'' a work drawing on tunes and images from Alley Oop, Popeye the Sailor Man and, of course, that famous bikini song.

docs.abstract: Article argues that if IOC awards 2008 Olympic Games to China, it is turning blind eye to egregous human right violations taking place every day there; holds letting games be held in China would permit authoritarian regime to exploit Games to prop up its faltering legitimacy and to gain important symbol of acceptance from international community; photo (M)

headline.main: BackTalk; I.O.C. Should Reject China for 2008

docs.snippet: On Friday, delegates of the International Olympic Committee will assemble in Moscow to vote to determine which city -- Toronto, Paris or Beijing -- will have the privilege of being host to the 2008 Summer Games. China's leaders have argued that polit
docs.lead_paragraph: On Friday, delegates of the International Olympic Committee will assemble in Moscow to vote to determine which city -- Toronto, Paris or Beijing -- will have the privilege of being host to the 2008 Summer Games. China's leaders have argued that politics should not taint the delegates' deliberations and that each finalist should be subject only to technical review to determine which city has the best sports facilities, transportation systems, hotels and other material resources needed to carry out a successful Olympics. But turning a blind eye to the egregious human rights violations taking place every day in China does not remove politics from the Olympics -- it permits an authoritarian regime to exploit the Games to prop up its faltering legitimacy by gaining an important symbol of acceptance from the international community. The I.O.C. should reject China's bid and protect the Olympic ideal.

docs.abstract: Beijing is clear favorite to host 2008 Summer Games; IOC will vote shortly; other cities being considered are Paris and Toronto (M)

headline.main: Beijing Expected to Receive the 2008 Summer Games When the I.O.C. Votes

docs.snippet: As members of the International Olympic Committee begin gathering on Friday in Moscow for a vote to name the host city for the 2008 Summer Games, Beijing remains a clear favorite over Paris and Toronto, according to Olympic officials and other inside
docs.lead_paragraph: As members of the International Olympic Committee begin gathering on Friday in Moscow for a vote to name the host city for the 2008 Summer Games, Beijing remains a clear favorite over Paris and Toronto, according to Olympic officials and other insiders. There appears to be a strong sense among I.O.C. delegates that the Summer Games belong in the world's most populous country and a belief that the Games could help to open Chinese society the way the awarding of the 1988 Olympics hastened the transition of South Korea from a military dictatorship to a democracy.
